search.slidetext: learn how to navigate this course in 5 minutes. get started! financial literacy go! go! go! learn to earn, save, spend, borrow wisely objective 03 03 gain a feeling of control over your money objective 02 02 build confidence with your finances. objective 01 01
go! go! go! tap the button
phone phone phone computer computer computer are you on a phone or a computer?
swipe to the left to continue
click next to continue
click back to go back
click next to continue
click the glossary tab on the menu to see definitions of key terms then click next to continue
click the menu tab to see a list of slides then click next to continue
click the computer – summary title on the menu tab to jump to the summary slide.

click the menu to jump to a specific slide click glossary to see definitions of words click the menu 03 click next to continue click back to go back click to move 02 click buttons to take actions or make decisions on the slide click the buttons 01 sumamry navigation go! go! go!
swipe to the right to go back
swipe to the left to continue
tap the menu icon to see the menu and glossary. tap the menu icon again to close. then swipe left to continue.

tap the menu to jump to a specific slide tap glossary to see definitions of words tap the menu 03 swipe left to go forward swipe right to go back swipe to move 02 tap buttons to take actions and make decisions on the slide tap the buttons 01 sumamry navigation go! go! go!

15 minutes banking learn to earn financial literacy go! go! go! explain how to open a bank account. objective 03 03 identify the purpose of banks. objective 02 02 name 2 sources of income. objective 01 01
describe two types of bank accounts. objective 03 03 identify the benefits of banks. objective 02 02 name 2 sources of income. objective 01 01 objectives earning
tap here to type in the code go! go! go! earning pre-test how much do you know? complete the pre-test to unlock the code. then tap go! to continue.
what is earning? earning money is when you receive money from working at a job or from government assistance programs. 01 earning
what is income? earning the money you take home is called your income. your income can change every month and come from many sources. 02

how do you get income? earning you may receive your income in different ways (not just cash): 03 work earnings paid through a check from your employer food stamps, wicreceived on a card you can use in stores ssi & tanf benefitspaid through a check from the government
sources of income earning help asha decide if this is a source of income by tapping yes or no: no no no yes yes yes start! start! start! 0/6

income is money you take home. there are many sources of income you may have. you may be paid in cash, by check or receive money on a government-issued card such as wic, snap, or tanf. lottery tickets, coupons and credit cards are not sources of income. earning sources of income go! go! go!

how much does it cost to cash a check you receive from your employer at the bank? cashing checks each bank charges a different fee. each bank charges a different fee. each bank charges a different fee. each bank charges a different fee. each bank charges a different fee. each bank charges a different fee. it costs $2.00 per check. it costs $2.00 per check. it costs $2.00 per check. it costs $2.00 per check. it costs $2.00 per check. it costs $2.00 per check. earning check answer check answer check answer it’s free to cash a check at the bank. it’s free to cash a check at the bank. it’s free to cash a check at the bank. it’s free to cash a check at the bank. it’s free to cash a check at the bank. it’s free to cash a check at the bank.

the bank lets you trade in your checks for cash without charging a fee. cashing a check is free putting money in your account helps you not spend money unwisely. banks help you save money the bank keeps your money protected from fires and theft. banks keep your money safe a bank is a financial institution that holds and lends money. what is a bank? earning

credit unions are non-profit financial groups where members own the institution and make decisions based on members’ needs and desires. what is a credit union? earning you may need to live in a certain area or work a certain job to join. you need to be a member credit unions offer more personal care and attention than bigger banks. locally owned credit unions sometimes provide better benefits than banks. credit unions are like banks
people usually have 2 accounts in a bank or credit union: bank accounts earning a savings account a checking account
checking account your checking account is active! checking account earning money comes in and goes out often
checking account this account is linked to your debit card and check book. checking account earning you can withdraw money easily.
savings account checking account you can transfer money to and from your savings account. bank accounts earning
savings account this account is for money that you save for future purchases. savings account earning only take money out of this account when you need it.

it’s safer to keep your money at home because the bank could get robbed and your money would be stolen. answer the questions to add money to your savings account! true or false? true true true true true true false false false false false false earning savings account

the only way to check how much money you have in your account is to go to the bank and ask. answer the questions to add money to your savings account! true or false? true true true true true true false false false false false false earning savings account

you need a lot of money to open a bank account. answer the questions to add money to your savings account! true or false? true true true true true true false false false false false false earning savings account
savings account you’re on your way to financial success! congratulations! earning swipe or click next to take a short feedback survey.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

terms.term: A financial institution that holds customers’ money, lends money, and exchanges currency. You can open an account with a government ID and a small amount of money.
A plastic card from a government program that has a certain amount of money that you can spend by swiping or inserting it in machines at a store. Example: SNAP, WIC, TANF (see also: credit card)
Paper or coin money (different from checks or cards)
A paper document that you sign that tells the bank to allow a person or company to take money from your bank account.
A non-profit financial group where members own the institution and make decisions based on members’ needs and desires.
To receive money from working at a job or from government assistance programs (to make money).
Money that you take home from working at a job or from government assistance programs.
